content.content: Responsible Oracle Migration Proposal For additional context, please review the Oracles V2 Announcement and listen to the Governance Call from September 5th. This proposal addresses primitives introduced in the Oracle Incentives Restructuring proposal. This proposal will have no effect if the Oracle Incentives Restructuring proposal is not ratified by MKR governors. If accepted, this proposal will:  Waive the Oracle Fee and allow any entity to be added to the whitelist. This will enable them to read prices from one or more Oracles for free for one year. The one year interval is specific to each entity. Guarantee the Oracle V1 infrastructure will stay live until at least global settlement of SCD (Single Collateral Dai).  Conducting the migration from Oracles V1 to Oracles V2 in this manner makes a lot of sense from a variety of angles. Benefiting Users It’s necessary to contextualize the state of the Oracle ecosystem as it is today. MakerDAO’s Oracles were the first on the Ethereum mainnet, dating as far back as May 2016. They are a completely open, public utility that anyone can access. This led to them being integrated in dozens of projects. In particular, proliferation throughout the DeFi ecosystem and Ethereum initiatives such as ENS, made them a vital keystone. Unfortunately, due to the Oracle’s permissionless nature, it is unknown just how many projects have integrated the Oracles. One of the reasons for integrating a whitelist into the Oracles in the first place is to get this transparent visibility of “who is using the Oracles” and “how are they using them”. Considering this entangled ecosystem of users, it is imperative that Maker governors act as good-citizens and conduct the migration to Oracles V2 in a responsible and thoughtful manner. “Pulling the rug out” so to speak is not a viable option. By overlapping Oracles V1 and Oracles V2, and waiving the Oracle Fee for one year, we give our users, and the ecosystem, time to plan their migration in a way that is convenient for them and their users. Take, for example, Gnosis who is using Oracles V1 in their DutchX Exchange. The DutchX smart contracts require a one month delay for swapping the Oracles. This is on top of the time it takes for Gnosis’ operations to evaluate, plan, and conduct the Oracle swap. By extending the service period of Oracles V1, and permitting free access to Oracles V2, we alleviate time pressures and facilitate the migration process. Bootstrapping the Ecosystem New projects are built on Ethereum everyday. Many of them require Oracles, but lack the resources to purchase them. If given the opportunity to succeed, many of these projects could become future customers. By offering Oracles for free for one year, we may find an equilibrium point where MakerDAO can take a leadership position through supporting innovation and still benefit from a long-term relationship. After the one year trial, projects will have the option to continue the service by paying the Oracle Fee as set by MKR governors. At that point, these projects will have already built their product on top of the Oracles, have a good sense for how reliable and valuable the Oracle service is, and may view Maker on good-terms due to the one year of free service. That is an exceptional position to be in when convincing customers to purchase the Oracle service. Free Trial Application Process To apply for the one year free trial, prospective clients will need to submit a proposal to the Oracles Forum. This application must include several pertinent pieces of information for MKR governors to evaluate and verify. Oracle Access Proposal Format:  Which Oracle(s) are desired (i.e., ETHUSD, ZRXUSD). Note this can include Oracles that don’t exist yet and are not collateral types in the Maker Protocol. The contract address(es) that need to be whitelist. Confirmation that the smart contract(s) source code has been verified on etherscan. Confirmation that the applicant understands the Oracle prices must have a private scope within their system. In other words, there is no public facing variable that can be queried by any entity to circumvent the whitelist. A plain english description of how the Oracle data will be utilized. Keybase username for point of contact. This will be utilized to alert and discuss potential future updates, migration plans, and for emergency scenarios such as an Oracle attack.  It is the responsibility of the Oracle Team(s) and MKR Governors to verify the information posted in applications. MKR Governors may modify the format of the Oracle Access Proposal and request additional information at any time. At the end of the evaluation cycle, all approved applications will be rolled up into a single executive proposal which will add them to the relevant Oracle whitelists.

Loving the initiative here. Makes a lot of sense both in terms of feed consumers and MKR Token Holders. A couple of points of the free trial application process though.     NikKunkel:  Confirmation that the applicant understands the Oracle prices must have a private scope within their system. In other words, there is no public facing variable that can be queried by any entity to circumvent the whitelist.   For this we’ll need to judge the contract code verified on etherscan. As much as we should also make sure consumers understand this intent, we need to ensure this is the case for ourselves.     NikKunkel:  A plain english description of how the Oracle data will be utilized.   Super important, this point should definitely be emphasized to any applicants.     NikKunkel:  It is the responsibility of the Oracle Team(s) and MKR Governors to verify the information posted in applications. MKR Governors may modify the format of the Oracle Access Proposal and request additional information at any time. At the end of the evaluation cycle, all approved applications will be rolled up into a single executive proposal which will add them to the relevant Oracle whitelists.   I feel like this should be clarified. The responsibility shouldn’t be shared in this way, it leaves it open for either group to say something along the lines of ‘I thought x verified it.’ On balance I feel like the responsibility for verification should lie solely with the Oracle Team, with the caveat that the Oracle Team is open to recruit/employ volunteers in the form of community members or MTH’s (Maker Token Holders) to do the work if they are overstretched or want a second set of eyes. This semi-formal deputization will also allow the Interim Oracle Team to begin training interested community members to join or form their own Oracle teams. The MTH’s responsibility kicks in with the single executive proposal, only at this point is it their job to briefly sanity check the Oracle Teams nominations. It’s unreasonable to expect every MTH to verify what could be tens or hundreds of oracle access proposals. At some level the MTH are going to need to trust that Oracle Team(s) are acting honestly, which is why I believe that the responsibility should lie with them. In a situation where a feed consumer republishes the oracle data publicly the MTH are on the hook for the lost income, but the fault lies with the elected experts who recommended the course of action (IE the Oracle Team) rather than the self-interested amateurs who passed the motion.

LongForWisdom:  For this we’ll need to judge the contract code verified on etherscan. As much as we should also make sure consumers understand this intent, we need to ensure this is the case for ourselves. On balance I feel like the responsibility for verification should lie solely with the Oracle Team, with the caveat that the Oracle Team is open to recruit/employ volunteers in the form of community members or MTH’s (Maker Token Holders) to do the work if they are overstretched or want a second set of eyes. The MTH’s responsibility kicks in with the single executive proposal, only at this point is it their job to  briefly  sanity check the Oracle Teams nominations.   I agree that the Oracle Team(s) are likely best qualified to do this and should shoulder that responsibility. My hesitation in specifying it in this manner initially is I’m not sure how much “sovereignty” MTH want to give up to Oracle Teams. I think for this particular instance, we can change the proposal to require Oracle Teams to sign-off on the claims presented in the applications. That being said, there’s a bigger issue this touches on. At what point does it become “the Oracle Team said to pass this, so my vote is just a rubber stamp” vs “this proposal was validated in part by community consensus, I feel comfortable voting for this”? The former entails more risk from malicious Oracle Teams.

NikKunkel:  That being said, there’s a bigger issue this touches on. At what point does it become “the Oracle Team said to pass this, so my vote is just a rubber stamp” vs “this proposal was validated in part by community consensus, I feel comfortable voting for this”? The former entails more risk from malicious Oracle Teams.   As always the trade-off is between security and convenience. I wonder if we should designate an additional type of team whose specific role is to validate the work of the other teams on behalf of token holders generally. This team would consist of generalists who would would both provide a useful role, and could also help to feed personnel into the other teams as expansion becomes necessary. My worry is that if we leave the community to validate proposals without organisation then at some point the community engagement will stop silently, with everyone assuming it’s happening even though it really isn’t.
The Responsible Oracle Migration Proposal has been submitted to the Governance Portal for a Polling Vote here. Please go vote, and let your voice be heard.
